Seed dispersal plays a crucial role in the reproductive success of plants by facilitating several key functions. Firstly, it helps in reducing competition among offspring. When seeds are dispersed away from the parent plant, they have a better chance of finding suitable habitat with ample resources such as nutrients, water, and sunlight, which are essential for their growth and survival.

Secondly, seed dispersal aids in the colonization of new habitats. By spreading seeds over a wider area, plants can expand their range and occupy new environments, which can be particularly important for species survival in changing climates or environments.
